header.title: Wes Anderson's Dream Sequence: Moonrise Kingdom
Moonrise Kingdom

header.author: Spencer Webb

p.opinions: Wes Anderson's 2012 film is wondrous in nature and evokes a nostalgic feeling of childhood.strong start

intro.p: Moonrise Kingdom explores adventure, romance, and mysticism through a child's point of view. The movie takes place in 1965 on an island called New Penzance. On one side of the island resides Camp Ivanhoe and Troop 55. Early in the film, the least popular scout of Troop 55, Sam, goes missing. On the other side of the island lives a young girl named Suzy who is often looking through her binoculars. She is twelve years old, the same as Sam, and lives with her dysfunctional family. She disappears as well. Shortly after, we learn that the reason for the disappearance of the two is each other. The film follows them as they traverse the island looking for a remote cove using the outdoor skills Sam acquired during his time in Troop 55. We see Sam and Suzy have their first kiss and express what they feel is love for each other. They decide that they don't like the map's name for the cove so they rename it. Soon after, they are discovered by the island officer Captain Sharp, as well as Suzy's parents and the Scout Master Ward. We learn that Sam is orphaned and his foster parents don't want him back. They are separated and Captain Sharp learns that Sam will have to be taken into Social Services. Sam is staying with Captain Sharp in the time being. The troop sneaks Sam out and they row to a neighbor island and camp. There Sam and Suzy have a pseudo-marriage from a troop member’s cousin, which has no legal binding, but has emotional ties. They then begin their escape as a storm is brewing in the background. They are spotted and chased as fugitives. While running, Sam is struck by lightning but miraculously recovers almost instantly. The storm picks up drastically and everyone including the Social Service Agent, the troop and Scout Master Ward, Captain Sharp, Suzy's parents, and Sam and Suzy themselves take cover in the church where Sam and Suzy first met. Sam and Suzy escape to the church steeple, expecting to be separated upon capture. Concerned about their well-being, Captain Sharp offers to take Sam in after having spent time with him earlier. Sam agrees. Some time later we see Sam sneaking into Suzy's home in an island officer uniform with a painting of the remote cove they stayed at. We learn that they decided to name the cove 'Moonrise Kingdom'.I like the use of the plot points. It makes the events of the movie easier to read and understand.

body.p: Wes Anderson is popular for his unique directing style. Often his films follow an almost dreamlike sequence. This movie is no different and provides a strange sense of wonder that is hard to pinpoint, but that viewers can attest to.does this relate in any way to the content of the movie or is it purely stlistic? What elements contribute to this dreamlike quality? The isolated setting of an island allows for a community with values and oddities of any sort, which Anderson loves doing. The cast isn't an all-star cast my any means. Bruce Willis is cast as Captain Sharp in a role that almost feels out of place for the traditional action movie star, but his performance is remarkable and emotional, as to be expected from such a high-profile actor. Bill Murray is cast as Suzy's father which I think works well as he can play any role where the director wants a little bit of sort of cool-strangeness that comes out in any character Bill Murray plays.examples of this or comparisons to his other roles (especially in Wes Anderson movies)?

p.aesthetics: Wes Anderson employs long and shifting camera pans which helps to give the movie a mystical feel. There is also an almost sepia color filter over the whole movie which adds to the artistic value of the shots. There is a lot of color contrast throughout the film which changes as the movie goes on and the storm brews which I think helps the viewer adjust to the mood change. There is also constantly light, fast-paced music playing in the background which smooths the transitions and reminds the viewer that much of the movie is from a child's point of view. There are also many intentionally silly effects such as when Sam is struck by lightning and when Scout Master Ward jumps over the flood. This serves to add to the dreamlike feel of the film.this is a strong paragraph

conclusion.p: Another Wes Anderson film I recently watched was Fantastic Mr. Fox which was released three years prior. Fantastic Mr. Fox was an entirely animated filmclaymation, right? while Moonrise Kingdom only had occasional cuts to animation, however it also showed many of the artistic creativities demonstrated in Moonrise Kingdom. Both films embodied the sense of dreaminess and mysticism and did a wonderful job evoking a deep nostalgic wonder despite the drastic difference in actual content. One thing I would have liked to have seen more in Moonrise Kingdom was character background. We know Sam is a somewhat troubled orphan but not much else about his relations with his troop and Scout Master.

p.opinions: The artistic value alone makes this movie worth seeing. I have grown to love Wes Anderson's style as it gives me the sense of wonder I was talking about more than many other movie types. I would compare the sense of wonder as similar to that of Studio Ghibli moviesinteresting comparison, which I am a big fan of as well. Anyone looking for a unique, mystical, nostalgia-provoking movie experience should definitely give this movie a watch.

conclusion.p: Moonrise Kingdom had an estimated budget of 16 million dollars, and grossed a little over 45 and a half million, making it quite successful. It premiered in the United States on May 25th and collected almost 523,000 dollars during its opening weekend.

report.p: The draft is reviewing the Wes Anderson film Moonrise Kingdom. The plot is explained, the film is analyzed in the context of the director and main actors, the aesthetics of the movie are reviewed, and it is compared to another film, Fantastic Mr. Fox. The plot is explained very well, and my only complaint is that I think you could add one or two sentences at the beginning to explain the background behind the setting or the characters. (Later you did mention that there wasn’t much background information given on the characters, but at least a short description of what is known about them will help). The next paragraph refers to the director, Wes Anderson, and the actors. I like the referencing of Wes Anderson throughout the review because it adds perspective and it also seems more credible when you can compare this movie with his other work. I think analyzing specific plot points or events of the movie is a good idea, because most of your analysis is in the form of comparisons or more general statements about the film. More of a defined statement can be made in the conclusion, because I don’t think it reinforces the rest of the review as well as it could. Overall I think what you wrote was very strong, and you mostly need to add more opinions/reactions/analysis relating to the synopsis, modify the conclusion to address your previous paragraphs and claims you made, and to smooth out the beginning of the synopsis.

This is a solid review. You have an appropriate level of detail throughout, I especially like your aesthetics paragraph, as it really helps establish your earlier claim of dreamlike/nostalgia, etc. One potential critique/question I had was whether or not you wanted to reveal the entire plot at the outset, given that some readers might be trying to decide whether to watch the movie, and maybe don't want to know when the kids are discovered, or whatever. Just a thought.
